School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Hefei University of Technology Hefei Anhui 230009 China 1 These authors contributed equally to this work. Oxygen cathode catalysts can significantly address the issues faced by Li-O2 battery. In this research, a composite of IrO2 nanoparticles grown in situ on BCN nanotubes (IrO2@BCNNTs) has been synthesized by facile hydrothermal method, which is initially fabricated as cathode catalyst for Li−O2 battery. The results indicate that IrO2@BCNNTs nanocomposite has a better effect on improving the actual discharge capacity, voltage gap and cyclability of Li−O2 battery. In addition, it is also demonstrated that the IrO2@BCNNTs composite exhibits bifunctional characteristics for both the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) through rotating disk electrode (RDE) measurements. The excellent performances of the synthesized catalyst may be attributed to the unique interconnected tubular structure and strong synergistic effect, which can provide more charged sites and defect sites and then facilitate reversible Li2O2 formation and decomposition. Therefore, it is promising for applying the rational design of the bifunctional catalyst to Li−O2 battery. Graphical abstract The IrO2@BCNNTs composite possesses tubular structure and large specific surface, which can produce more charged sites and defect sites to facilitate the O2 adsorption and the formation/decomposition of Li2O2. Image, graphical abstract Keywords BCN nanotubes IrO2@BCNNTs composite Rechargeable Li−O2 batteries 1 Introduction In the development of human history, the dependence on non-renewable resources has caused a series of issues with global climate change, energy security and sustainability. To address these issues effectively, the development of next-generation superior energy storage technology has been the indispensable strategy [1–3]. After several decades of exploration, rechargeable Li-O2 batteries have attracted enormous research attention beyond traditional Li-ion batteries, and seem to be a promising alternative in electric vehicles because of their high theoretical energy density [4–8]. However, the Li-O2 batteries still remain many plagued challenges, such as limited cyclic performance, capacity fading, high overpotential, and instability of electrolyte [9–13]. Among these challenges, the most significant challenge is the sluggish kinetics, which limits the application of Li-O2 battery. In a nonaqueous Li−O2 battery, the formation and decomposition of Li2O2 on the cathode surface during the discharging process (ORR, O2+2Li++2e−→Li2O2) and the charging process (OER, Li2O2→O2+2Li++2e−) should be reversible theoretically. Actually, the reversible reaction is not sufficient which may passivate the cathode, causing premature battery death [14,15]. Thus, it is highly desirable to find an effective way to ameliorate this situation. According to previous research, the electrocatalysts can play the role of redox mediator, which next can act as electron-hole transfer agent to facilitate the formation and decomposition of Li2O2 [16]. So far, many catalytic materials have been investigated and reported, such as noble metals and alloys, transition metal oxides and their composites, functional carbon materials [4,17–26]. However, they inevitably suffer from high material cost, poor chemical stability, low efficiency, and low electronic conductivity, which impede the wide use as electrodecatalysts in Li-O2 battery. Boron carbon nitride (BCN) has a layer structure similar to graphite structure, which can be synthesized easily. Furthermore, no any metal element was involved in the process [27–30]. In the history of BCN material development, mechanical property, thermal conductivity, field emission properties, X-rays characteristic and structure stability were studied [31–35]. In addition, it was found that BCN material has many characteristics, such as low cost, high stability, low mass, porosity, and long-term durability. Due to these excellent characteristics, it has been applied in many fields such as photology, mechanics and electrochemistry [36–38]. However, few investigations have been carried out on BCN material as electrocatalyst applied in nonaqueous Li-O2 batteries. Wang et al. [28] reported that (1) the N and B co-doping can greatly increase the synergetic effect and the high thermal stability, which make BCN material attractive for metal-free ORR electrocatalysts; (2) appropriate ratio of B, C and N elements can decrease the energy bandgap, improve atomic spin density and charge density, which are beneficial to ameliorate chemical reactivity. Zhao et al. [39] reported that the N and B co-doping could activate the carbon π electrons in electron-rich sp2 carbon materials, which would create more charged sites to favor O2 adsorption. So far, some researchers devote their effort to BCN material for ORR. Not satisfactorily, these results showed that the ORR performance of BCN material is still far worse than commercial Pt/C material. Moreover, few studies have been involved in the OER character. To provide superior ORR and OER performances simultaneously, we put forward that the BCN material should be modified by other metal oxides. As an excellent OER catalyst, IrO2 has been applied in different fields, such as fuel cell [40], water electrolysis [41] and metal-O2 batteries [42]. Thus, combining BCN with IrO2 can theoretically provide bifunctional catalysis and enhance the electrocatalytic activity. Herein, the composite (IrO2@BCNNTs) was prepared by growing IrO2 nanoparticles in situ on BCN nanotubes. As a contrast, the composite (C-IrO2@BCNNTs) was synthesized by the commercial IrO2 nanoparticles directly combined with BCN nanotubes using hydrothermal method. Both composite materials were used as electrocatalyst for rechargeable Li-O2 battery in organic electrolyte. Through a variety of electrochemical tests, the results showed that the IrO2@BCNNTs composite exhibits remarkably electrocatalytic activity for ORR and OER than C-IrO2@BCNNTs composite. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of BCN nanotubes The BCN nanotubes were prepared by pyrolysis. Urea (2.5 g), PEG-2000 (0.25 g) and boric acid (0.075 g) were weighed and dissolved fully in 50 mL deionized water, then the mixed solution was transferred to an oven at 120 °C for 15 h, and eventually pyrolyzed at 900 °C for 6 h under inert gas atmosphere (Ar). 2.2 Synthesis of IrO2@BCNNTs composite 0.2 g as-prepared BCN nanotubes and 0.084 g Ircl3•xH2O were dissolved in 50 mL deionized water, then was treated by stirring for 30 min, and ultrasonic dispersion for 30 min. Subsequently, the mixed solution was put into a 50 mL Teflon-lined autoclave at 180 °C for 24 h. After cooling down to the room temperature, the resulting product was centrifuged and washed thoroughly, and then transferred in a vacuum drying oven at 90 °C for 10 h. Finally, the obtained black solid power was annealed in a muffle furnace at 400 °C for 3 h. 2.3 Synthesis of C-IrO2@BCNNTs composite The synthetic route of C-IrO2@BCNNTs composite is similar to IrO2@BCNNTs composite. The only difference is that the preparation material is commercial IrO2 and no calcining at 400 °C in the last step. 2.4 Material characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of materials were examined on a CMA X'Pert PRO MPD X-ray diffractometer with Cu-Kα radiation from 10° to 80° (2θ). The morphology and structure of all samples were examined by field-emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM, SU8020, Hitachi). Transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEM-2100F, Hitachi) and energy-dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) at 200 kV. The element composition and valance were analyzed by the X-ray Photoemission Spectroscopy (XPS) on a Rigaku D/MAX2500V using Al Kα source. The specific surface areas and pore size distributions were obtained from N2 adsorption and desorption test by using a Quantachrome VersaWin analyzer. 2.5 Electrochemical measurements The ORR and OER performances of the as-synthesized catalysts were examined by the rotating disk electrode (RDE, ATA-B), which is a three-electrode system with O2 saturated 0.1 M KOH as electrolyte. To prepare the working electrode, 2 mg XC-72, 10 mg catalyst sample, 40 µL 5 wt% Nafion were weighed and dissolved in 2 mL water/isopropanol solution (5:1, v:v), sonicated for more than 1 h. Then, 5 µL of the slurry was dropped onto the eletrode surface, which was polished by γ-alumina powder. Drying for a few hours later at room temperature, the catalytic layer was formed. On the Autolab electrochemical workstation (CHI604d), using the linear scanning voltammetry (LSV) procedure can examine the electrochemical activities within a voltage range from 0.1 to −0.7 V (ORR) and a voltage range from 0 to 1.0 V (OER). In order to understand the electrochemical performances of different materials as catalysts in nonaqueous Li−O2 battery, 2032-type coin cells having holes in the cathode side were assembled. To prepare the O2 cathode before assembling, XC-72, catalyst sample and PVDF (6:3:1, wt%) were mixed and grinded as homogeneous ink, which subsequently was coated on carbon paper homogeneously (the catalyst mass loading was about 0.3–0.5 mg cm−2), and then transferred to the vacuum drying oven at 90 °C for 10 h. Each test cell should be assembled as follows: the anode (a lithium wafer), the separator (a glassy fiber, Whatman grade GF/D), the electrolyte (1 M LiCF3SO3 in TEGDME), the oxygen cathode (carbon paper supported catalysts) and the filler (two pieces of nickel foam, 1 mm thick). It should be noted that the assembling operation was in an argon-filled glove-box (moisture and oxygen contents <0.1 ppm) and the performances test was on the battery testing system (Neware, CT-4008). All the cell tests were conducted under run continuous flow of O2 and O2 pressure of 1 atm at room temperature. 3 Results and discussion Fig. 1 shows the schematic illustration of the fabrication process and the possible mechanism of the IrO2@BCNNTs catalyst. Through the hydrothermal treatment, Ircl3 hydrate became iridium oxide due to substitution reaction on the surface of BCN nanotubes. After calcining treatment, the iridium oxide further transformed to the IrO2 nanoparticles, which facilitate the ORR/OER reactions with BCN nanotubes synergistically. XRD patterns of the BCN nanotubes (red line), the IrO2@BCNNTs composite (blue line), the C-IrO2@BCNNTs composite (purple line) and the standard IrO2 PDF card (black line) are shown in Fig. 2 (a). For the BCN nanotubes, it can be observed that there are two XRD peaks at 26° and 43°, which respectively correspond to (002) and (100) diffraction planes. In addition, it can be demonstrated that the BCN nanotubes exist as graphitic structure [43]. For the XRD pattern of IrO2@BCNNTs composite, the typical reflection peaks at 2θ of 28.1°, 34.9°, 40.2°, 54.2°, 58.3°, 66.3° can be indexed to IrO2 referring to the standard IrO2 PDF card (a 0=b 0=4.505 Å, space group P42/mnm (136), PDF#88–0288). Meanwhile, it can be observed that there are two XRD peaks at 26° and 43°, which respectively correspond to (002) and (100) diffraction planes of BCN nanotubes. Apparently, the co-existence of two ingredients synthesized in the composite has been confirmed. For the XRD pattern of C-IrO2@BCNNTs composite, it also can be confirmed that commercial IrO2 successfully combined with BCN nanotubes. Fig. 2(b and c) displays the SEM images of the BCNNTs and the commercial IrO2. The Fig. 2(b) clearly shows the BCN exists as nanotubular morphology with an average diameter of about 100 nm and tube length of more than 1um generally. As can be seen from the Fig. 2(c), the commercial IrO2 particles are dispersed unevenly with uneven diameter. Fig. 2(d) shows the SEM image of IrO2@BCNNTs composite. IrO2 nanoparticles synthesized in situ are supported on the surface of the BCN nanotubes, and the tubular structure is still kept. To acquire more information about the microstructures of two composite materials, high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM) was performed. Fig. 3 (a and b) displays the TEM images of IrO2@BCNNTs composite under different magnification. It can be observed that IrO2 nanoparticles synthesized in situ are dispersed uniformly on the surface of the BCN nanotubes, which is in agreement with SEM images. Moreover, it can illustrate that the interaction of two ingredients is so strong that they can't be separated by ultrasonic treatment during TEM preparation. Fig. 3(c) shows the TEM image of C-IrO2@BCNNTs composite. In contrast to the IrO2@BCNNTs composite, the commercial IrO2 nanoparticles are dispersed unevenly owing to uneven particle size. Fig. 3(d) shows the HR-TEM image of IrO2@BCNNTs composite. Two lattice fringes with interlayer distance of 0.258 nm and 0.169 nm can be observed, which coincide with the adjacent spacing of the (101) plane and (211) plane of the IrO2 nanoparticles, respectively. The interlayer distance of 0.340 nm can be attributed to the (002) planes of BCN nanotubes [44]. Based on the above characterization analysis, we can affirm the IrO2@BCNNTs composite and C-IrO2@BCNNTs composite have been synthesized successfully. To clearly observe the distribution of elements, energy-dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) mapping was carried out. From Fig. 4 (a and b), the distributions of elements of two composite materials are different obviously. It can be observed that the IrO2 nanoparticles in the IrO2@BCNNTs composite distribute more uniformly than the C-IrO2@BCNNTs composite, which is highly consistent with SEM and TEM analysis. N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm measurement was employed to analyze the surface area, pore volume and pore width of above materials. The isotherm curve (Fig. 5 ) exhibits a type-IV feature with pronounced adsorption, which indicates that there are a large number of mesopores and macropores in IrO2@BCNNTs composite [45]. From the Table 1 , the surface area of up to 360.663 m2 g−1 for IrO2@BCNNTs composite, which is much higher than C-IrO2@BCNNTs composite. Furthermore, the pore volume of the IrO2@BCNNTs composite is 1.177 cm3 g−1, much larger than the C-IrO2@BCNNTs composite. According to previous research, the IrO2@BCNNTs composite has large specific surface area, which not only can create more catalyst sites for electrolyte, O2 and Li2O2 but also can facilitate Li+ ions transport and decomposition of Li2O2 [46]. The IrO2@BCNNTs composite is also confirmed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). From the XPS survey spectra (Fig. 6 a), we can easily observe the peaks of B 1s (~192.1 eV), N 1s (~399.6 eV), Ir 4f (~64.1 eV), Ir 4p (~496.1 eV) and O 1s (~532.1 eV), which demonstrate the existence of two monomer materials in this composite. Fig. 6(b) shows the peaks of B species. The N − B − C bond is associated with the peak at 191.3 eV and another peak at 192.2 eV can be assigned to the B—C = O [29,39]. Fig. 6(c) shows various types of N-moieties, in which four fitted peaks locate at around 398.7, 399.5, 400.3, 401.5 eV respectively corresponded to N − B − C, pyridinic N, pyrrolic N, graphitic N [47,48]. In the Ir 4f spectra (Fig. 6d), the peaks at 61.3 eV and 64.4 eV can be assigned to Ir 4f 7/2 and Ir 4f 5/2 of Ir4+, while the peaks at 62.4 eV and 66.4 eV can be attributed to Ir 4f 7/2 and Ir 4f 5/2 of Ir x +. Estimated from the corresponding peaks areas, it can be easily found that Ir mainly existed as Ir4+ [49]. Fig. 6(e) shows three peaks of O species, which locate 530.0 eV, 531.7 eV and 533.1 eV respectively. Among them, the peak at 530.0 eV can be attributed to IrO2 single crystal [50]. To evaluate the electrocatalytic activity of each material, the LSV test was carried out in O2 saturated 0.1 M KOH as electrolyte [51,52]. Fig. 7 (a) displays the ORR polarization curves for BCN, IrO2@BCNNTs, C-IrO2@BCNNTs, XC-72 and Pt/C catalysts. It shows that the IrO2@BCNNTs composite catalyst exhibits an excellent ORR activity on the verge of Pt/C catalyst with more positive ORR onset potential (−0.707 V) and larger limiting current density (~4.43 mA cm−2) than BCN, C-IrO2@BCNNTs and XC-72, of which the onset potential and limiting current density are −0.123 V, −0.313 V, −0.239 V and ~3.53 mA cm−2, ~3.81 mA cm−2, ~1.86 mA cm−2, respectively. To figure out and confirm the number of electrons transfer during ORR, the Koutecky−Levich equation was introduced to calculate the number “n” [53]. (1) 1 j = 1 j K + 1 j L (2) j L = B ω 1 2 (3) B = 0.2 n F D 0 2 3 C 0 ν − 1 6 Where j K and j L are the kinetic current and limiting current density respectively; j is the observed current density; B is the Levich slope; ω is the electrode rotation speed; F represents the Faraday constant (96485C/mol); D 0 represents the diffusion coefficient of O2 in 0.1 M KOH (1.93 × 10−5 cm2/s); Co is the bulk concentration of O2 (1.126 × 10−6 mol/cm3); ν is the kinetic viscosity of the electrolyte (1.09 × 10−2 cm2/s). According to calculation of Fig. 7(b), the electron transfer numbers “n” of BCN, IrO2@BCNNTs, C-IrO2@BCNNTs, XC-72 and Pt/C are 2.7, 3.8, 3.0, 2.1 and 4.0, respectively. The electron transfer number of IrO2@BCNNTs composite is quite close to commercial Pt/C, which shows that the ORR process is four-electron reaction and a first-order kinetic characteristic with all plots showing a linear feature [54]. Fig. 7(c) shows the OER polarization curves of BCN, IrO2@BCNNTs, C-IrO2@BCNNTs, XC-72 and Pt/C. The IrO2@BCNNTs composite catalyst exhibits the best OER catalytic activity than BCN, C-IrO2@BCNNTs, XC-72 and Pt/C catalysts. For the limiting current density, the IrO2@BCNNTs composite is 51.2 mA cm−2, which is significantly higher than BCN (~5.0 mA cm−2), C-IrO2@BCNNTs (~15.3 mA cm−2), XC-72 (~2.9 mA cm−2) and Pt/C (~19.3 mA cm−2). For the process of ORR and OER, they can be summarized the followings: (4) ORR : O 2 + H 2 O + 2 e − → HO 2 − + O H − (5) HO 2 − + H 2 O + 2 e − → 3 O H − (6) OER : 4 O H − − 4 e − → O 2 + 2 H 2 O (6) can be split the following four steps: (7) O H − + * → * OH + e − (8) * OH + O H − → * O + H 2 O + e − (9) O H − + * O → * OOH + e − (10) * OOH + O H − → O 2 + H 2 O + e − Where * represents the absorbed state; *OH, *O, *OOH are transition products at absorbed state. Due to the process is four-electron reaction, proton transfer and electron transfer are simultaneous, which means above four steps are simultaneous, too. The results of ORR / OER tests of IrO2@BCNNTs composite catalyst showed good catalytic ability, and the calculation of Koutecky−Levich showed the whole four-electron reaction of the ORR/OER process. The great enhancement of catalytic reaction not only attributed to the inherent physical properties of materials (e.g., surface area and self-structure), but also more dependent on chemical factors. Hence, we can conclude that the strong synergistic effect of the IrO2@BCNNTs composite can create more charged sites and defect sites to facilitate the O2 adsorption. As a result, the IrO2@BCNNTs composite can show the most excellent catalytic performance. To explore the catalytic capacity of each sample employed as catalysts of Li-O2 batteries, 2032-type coin cells were assembled. Fig. 8 (a) shows the initial discharge capacity of the BCN, IrO2@BCNNTs, C-IrO2@BCNNTs. Obviously, the IrO2@BCNNTs composite catalyst shows the best high discharge capacity (9831 mA h g−1) rather than BCN catalyst (6148 mA h g−1) and C-IrO2@BCNNTs catalyst (7589 mA h g −1). From Fig. 8(b), the IrO2@BCNNTs composite catalyst enhances the minimum overpotential (1.08 V) than BCN catalyst (1.26 V) and C-IrO2@BCNNTs catalyst (1.23 V). Fig. 8(c and d) exhibits the cycle curves of BCN and IrO2@BCNNTs composite as catalysts of Li-O2 batteries when controlled under the current density of 500 mA g −1 and a fixed capacity of 1000 mA h g −1. Not surprisingly, the IrO2@BCNNTs composite catalyst still shows excellent cycling capacity (310 cycles) higher than the BCN catalyst (186 cycles). The results of ORR / OER polarization curves and cycling test both showed that the IrO2@BCNNTs composite has an outstanding catalytic ability, which may be related to the following reasons. Firstly, the BCN nanotubes rid itself of originally fragile CC bonds, which can ensure the composite enhances enduring stability in the continuous cyclic state. Secondly, the tubular porous structure not only can provide enough bonding sites for IrO2 nanoparticles but also substantial active sites for charge-discharge products. In addition, this structure can favor good electrolyte sufficiently wetting, which can facilitate fast O2 transport. To explain the catalytic reaction mechanism more clearly, the products on electrode with IrO2@BCNNTs catalyst during the discharge/charge process should be analyzed. Fig. 9 (a) shows the ex situ XRD spectras of the products on electrode after discharge/charge process at a current density of 100 mA g−1. Contrasted to the Li2O2 standard card (PDF#09–0355), the newly present peaks at 2θ=33.0°, 35.0°, and 58.8° can be traced to the Li2O2 without LiOH and Li2O, which indicates the primary product is Li2O2 after discharge process. After charge process, along with Li2O2 decomposition, the XRD spectra recovered consistently with the pristine. Namely, it can demonstrate that the cathode reaction catalyzed by IrO2@BCNNTs composite possesses excellent reversibility. To furtherly understand the reaction mechanism of the IrO2@BCNNTs composite during the whole catalytic process, the ex situ SEM images were also obtained from above three states (Fig. 9b–d). In the discharged state, it can be clearly observed that toroidal-like Li2O2 emerged on the cathode surface [55]. However, the toroidal-like Li2O2 totally disappeared and the cathode restored its pristine morphology after charging, which is in good agreement with XRD. 4 Conclusions To sum up, a new IrO2@BCNNTs composite was synthesized by facile hydrothermal method, which was firstly fabricated as bifunctional cathode electrocatalyst for Li−O2 battery. Series of characterization and testing were carried out. The results showed that the composite not only kept the tubular structure but also possessed large specific surface, which produced more charged sites and defect sites that could prompt such a strong synergistic effect to facilitate the O2 adsorption and the formation/decomposition of Li2O2. When the IrO2@BCNNTs composite fabricated as electrocatalyst for Li−O2 battery, the battery exhibited higher discharge capacity (~9831 mA h g−1), lower overpotential (~1.08 V) and more excellent cyclability (~310 cycles) than other electrocatalysts. Consequently, this research will guide a new view on the rational design of catalyst for Li-O2 battery. coredata.dc:description: Oxygen cathode catalysts can significantly address the issues faced by Li-O2 battery. In this research, a composite of IrO2 nanoparticles grown in situ on BCN nanotubes (IrO2@BCNNTs) has been synthesized by facile hydrothermal method, which is initially fabricated as cathode catalyst for Li−O2 battery. The results indicate that IrO2@BCNNTs nanocomposite has a better effect on improving the actual discharge capacity, voltage gap and cyclability of Li−O2 battery. In addition, it is also demonstrated that the IrO2@BCNNTs composite exhibits bifunctional characteristics for both the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) through rotating disk electrode (RDE) measurements. The excellent performances of the synthesized catalyst may be attributed to the unique interconnected tubular structure and strong synergistic effect, which can provide more charged sites and defect sites and then facilitate reversible Li2O2 formation and decomposition. Therefore, it is promising for applying the rational design of the bifunctional catalyst to Li−O2 battery.
